user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Hook_GetArgPtr:
```c
const void *UT_Hook_GetArgPtr(const UT_StubContext_t *ContextPtr, const char *Name, size_t ExpectedTypeSize)
{
    uint32                      i;
    const void *                Result;
    const UT_StubArgMetaData_t *MetaPtr;

    static const union
    {
        unsigned long AsInt;
        void *        AsPtr;
        double        AsFloat;
    } ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE = {0};

    Result = NULL;
    for (i = 0; i < ContextPtr->ArgCount; ++i)
    {
        MetaPtr = &ContextPtr->Meta[i];
        if (MetaPtr->Name != NULL)
        {
            if (strcmp(MetaPtr->Name, Name) == 0 && (MetaPtr->Size == 0 || MetaPtr->Size == ExpectedTypeSize))
            {
                if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_DIRECT)
                {
                    Result = &ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                else if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_INDIRECT)
                {
                    Result = ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                break;
            }
        }
    }

    /*
     * If no suitable result pointer was found, this means a mismatch
     * between the stub and test case, such as a change in argument/parameter names.
     * This is an error that should be corrected, so report it as a failure.
     */
    if (Result == NULL)
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("Requested parameter %s of size %lu which was not provided by the stub", Name,
                        (unsigned long)ExpectedTypeSize);

        if (ExpectedTypeSize <= sizeof(ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE))
        {
            Result = &ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * As the caller will likely dereference the returned pointer, should
             * never return NULL.  Just abort here.
             */
            UtAssert_Abort("No value for parameter");
        }
    }

    return Result;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Hook_GetArgPtr:
typedef struct
{
    int32                Int32StatusCode;
    bool                 Int32StatusIsSet;
    uint32               ArgCount;
    const void *         ArgPtr[UT_STUBCONTEXT_MAXSIZE];
    UT_StubArgMetaData_t Meta[UT_STUBCONTEXT_MAXSIZE];
} UT_StubContext_t
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_StubContext_Arg_Type_t Type;
    const char *              Name;
    size_t                    Size;
} UT_StubArgMetaData_t
...
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in this function are syntactically invariant (i.e., constant at compile time). The candidates that might be considered for Rule 14.3 are listed and justified as not requiring investigation:

- for (i = 0; i < ContextPtr->ArgCount; ++i)
  - The loop condition depends on the runtime value ContextPtr->ArgCount and the loop index i, so it is not an invariant controlling expression.

- if (MetaPtr->Name != NULL)
  - Depends on the runtime contents of MetaPtr->Name for the current element; not invariant.

- if (strcmp(MetaPtr->Name, Name) == 0 && (MetaPtr->Size == 0 || MetaPtr->Size == ExpectedTypeSize))
  - The strcmp result and MetaPtr->Size are runtime values; the composite expression is therefore not invariant.

- if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_DIRECT) / else if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_INDIRECT)
  - These tests depend on the runtime value MetaPtr->Type; not invariant.

- if (Result == NULL)
  - Result is assigned earlier based on loop/runtime checks; this is not a compile-time constant expression.

- if (ExpectedTypeSize <= sizeof(ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE))
  - Although sizeof(ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE) is a compile-time constant, the comparison involves the runtime parameter ExpectedTypeSize, so the controlling expression is not invariant.

- There are no do/while or while loops with constant controlling expressions (e.g., while(1) or for(;;)), and no other unconditional/compile-time-constant conditions present.

Given the above, there are no code fragments in UT_Hook_GetArgPtr that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 (controlling expressions shall not be invariant).
